channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: Poisoning AI Training Data
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: 'Richter Scale' Model Measures Magnitude of OT Cyber Incidents
item.description: ICS/OT experts have devised a scoring system for rating the severity and effects of cybersecurity events in operational technology environments.
item.dc:creator: Kelly Jackson Higgins

item.title: Manual Processes Are Putting National Security at Risk
item.description: Why automating sensitive data transfers is now a mission-critical priority More than half of national security organizations still rely on manual processes to transfer sensitive data, according to The CYBER360: Defending the Digital Battlespace report. This should alarm every defense and government leader because manual handling of sensitive data is not just inefficient, it is a systemic
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Former Defense Contractor Boss Gets 7+ Years for Selling Zero Days
item.description: A former general manager of a US defense contractor has been sentenced after selling zero days to Russia

item.title: ICO’s £14m Reddit Fine Highlights Age Check Privacy Concerns
item.description: The UK’s ICO has fined Reddit over £14m for failing to use children’s personal information lawfully

item.title: Defense Contractor Employee Jailed for Selling 8 Zero-Days to Russian Broker
item.description: A 39-year-old Australian national who was previously employed at U.S. defense contractor L3Harris has been sentenced to a little over seven years in prison for selling eight zero-day exploits to Russian exploit broker Operation Zero in exchange for millions of dollars. Peter Williams pleaded guilty to two counts of theft of trade secrets in October 2025. In addition to the jail term, Williams
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Operation Red Card 2.0 Leads to 651 Arrests in Africa
item.description: In the latest operation targeting cybercrime groups, African law enforcement agencies cooperated with Interpol and cybersecurity firms to recover more than USD 4.3 million.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos

item.title: SolarWinds Patches 4 Critical Serv-U 15.5 Flaws Allowing Root Code Execution
item.description:
SolarWinds has released updates to address four critical security flaws in its Serv-U file transfer software that, if successfully exploited, could result in remote code execution. The vulnerabilities, all rated 9.1 on the CVSS scoring system, are listed below -
CVE-2025-40538 - A broken access control vulnerability that allows an attacker to create a system admin user and execute arbitrary
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: The Vendor Tiering Series: Why Tier Your Vendors | UpGuard
item.description: When every vendor is a priority, none actually are. Learn how effective vendor tiering defines criticality and maintains a defensible security posture.

item.title: CISA Confirms Active Exploitation of FileZen CVE-2026-25108 Vulnerability
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Tuesday added a recently disclosed vulnerability in FileZen to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-25108 (CVSS v4 score: 8.7), is a case of operating system (OS) command injection that could allow an authenticated user to execute
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Attackers Now Need Just 29 Minutes to Own a Network
item.description: Credential misuse, AI tools, and security blind spots help attackers move through breached networks faster than ever, CrowdStrike finds.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan

item.title: Lazarus Group Picks a New Poison: Medusa Ransomware
item.description: The North Korean threat group also leveraged Comebacker backdoor, Blindingcan RAT, and info stealer Infohook in its recent attacks.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Google Alerts Users to Serious Chrome Bugs With Takeover Risk
item.description: <p>Google released a Chrome security update patching three high-severity vulnerabilities, including memory flaws that could enable remote attacks.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-google-chrome-high-severity-vulnerabilities-update-2026/">Google Alerts Users to Serious Chrome Bugs With Takeover Risk</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: iPhone Privacy Alert: Predator Spyware Can Hide Camera, Mic Indicators
item.description: <p>Predator spyware can suppress iOS camera and mic indicators after full device compromise, researchers say.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-predator-spyware-ios-privacy-dots/">iPhone Privacy Alert: Predator Spyware Can Hide Camera, Mic Indicators</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Kezia Jungco

item.title: RoguePilot Flaw in GitHub Codespaces Enabled Copilot to Leak GITHUB_TOKEN
item.description: A vulnerability in GitHub Codespaces could have been exploited by bad actors to seize control of repositories by injecting malicious Copilot instructions in a GitHub issue. The artificial intelligence (AI)-driven vulnerability has been codenamed RoguePilot by Orca Security. It has since been patched by Microsoft following responsible disclosure. "Attackers can craft hidden instructions inside a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Cost of Insider Incidents Surges 20% to Nearly $20m
item.description: DTEX claims insider incidents cost $19.5m in 2025, with employee negligence most expensive

item.title: Multifaceted Phishing Scheme Deceives Bitpanda Customers
item.description: Phishing attack mimicking Bitpanda targets users, harvesting credentials and personal information

item.title: North Korean Lazarus Group Expands Ransomware Activity With Medusa
item.description: Ransomware Medusa linked to North Korean hackers targets US healthcare amid ongoing attacks

item.title: UAC-0050 Targets European Financial Institution With Spoofed Domain and RMS Malware
item.description: A Russia-aligned threat actor has been observed targeting a European financial institution as part of a social engineering attack to likely facilitate intelligence gathering or financial theft, signaling a possible expansion of the threat actor's targeting beyond Ukraine and into entities supporting the war-torn nation. The activity, which targeted an unnamed entity involved in regional
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: As Cybersecurity Firms Chase AI, VC Market Skyrockets
item.description: Investments in cybersecurity startups took off in 2025 as venture capital firms focused not just on AI-native tech but on talent as well.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos

item.title: AI Accelerates Attacker Breakout Time to Just Four Minutes
item.description: ReliaQuest claims AI has reduced breakout and exfiltration time to under 10 minutes

item.title: Is AI Good for Democracy?
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Celebrating Two Years of CSF 2.0!
item.description: Celebrate this milestone with us! Email us at <span class="spamspan"><span class="u">csf</span> [at] <span class="d">nist.gov</span><span class="t"> (csf[at]nist[dot]gov)</span></span> or tag @NISTcyber on X telling us what your favorite CSF 2.0 resource is (or how your organization has benefitted from implementing the CSF 2.0). Today marks two years since the publication of the Cybersecurity Framework (CSF) 2.0! Published in 2024, the CSF 2.0 included the addition of a Govern Function, increased emphasis on cybersecurity supply chain risk management, updated categories and subcategories to address current threat and technology shifts, and expansion into a suite of resources designed to make the CSF 2.0 easier to
item.dc:creator: Stephen Quinn

item.title: Identity Prioritization isn't a Backlog Problem - It's a Risk Math Problem
item.description: Most identity programs still prioritize work the way they prioritize IT tickets: by volume, loudness, or “what failed a control check.” That approach breaks the moment your environment stops being mostly-human and mostly-onboarded. In modern enterprises, identity risk is created by a compound of factors: control posture, hygiene, business context, and intent. Any one of these can perhaps be
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Lazarus Group Uses Medusa Ransomware in Middle East and U.S. Healthcare Attacks
item.description: The North Korea-linked Lazarus Group (aka Diamond Sleet and Pompilus) has been observed using Medusa ransomware in an attack targeting an unnamed entity in the Middle East, according to a new report by the Symantec and Carbon Black Threat Hunter Team. Broadcom's threat intelligence division said it also identified the same threat actors mounting an unsuccessful attack against a healthcare
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Chinese AI Firms Hit Claude with Distillation Attacks, Anthropic Warns
item.description: Anthropic accused DeepSeek, Moonshot and MiniMax of illicitly using Claude to steal some of the AI model’s capabilities

item.title: AI-powered Cyber-Attacks Up Significantly in the Last Year, Warns CrowdStrike
item.description: CrowdStrike Global Threat Report warns how adversaries are leveraging AI to make campaigns more efficient and more effective

item.title: UnsolicitedBooker Targets Central Asian Telecoms With LuciDoor and MarsSnake Backdoors
item.description: The threat activity cluster known as UnsolicitedBooker has been observed targeting telecommunications companies in Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan, marking a shift from prior attacks aimed at Saudi Arabian entities. The attacks involve the deployment of two distinct backdoors codenamed LuciDoor and MarsSnake, according to a report published by Positive Technologies last week. "The group used several
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Anthropic Says Chinese AI Firms Used 16 Million Claude Queries to Copy Model
item.description: Anthropic on Monday said it identified "industrial-scale campaigns" mounted by three artificial intelligence (AI) companies, DeepSeek, Moonshot AI, and MiniMax, to illegally extract Claude's capabilities to improve their own models. The distillation attacks generated over 16 million exchanges with its large language model (LLM) through about 24,000 fraudulent accounts in violation of its terms
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Spitting Cash: ATM Jackpotting Attacks Surged in 2025
item.description: The attacks cost banks more than $20 million in losses last year, as criminals used many of the same tools and tactics they have wielded for more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan

item.title: More Than Dashboards: AI Decisions Must Be Provable
item.description: AI systems have to be able to show a record of what happened and how.
item.dc:creator: James Urquhart

item.title: Microsoft Copilot Ignored Sensitivity Labels, Processed Confidential Emails
item.description: <p>A code bug blew past every security label in the book… and exposed the fatal flaw in how we govern AI.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-copilot-bug-confidential-emails/">Microsoft Copilot Ignored Sensitivity Labels, Processed Confidential Emails</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Tim Freestone

item.title: Iran's MuddyWater Targets Orgs With Fresh Malware as Tensions Mount
item.description: The long-active Iranian threat group debuted various attack strains and payloads in attacks against organizations in the Middle East and Africa.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano

item.title: Enigma Cipher Device Still Holds Secrets for Cyber Pros
item.description: The Nazi relic's history is riddled with resilience errors, and those lessons still apply to defending against modern cyber threats.
item.dc:creator: Becky Bracken

item.title: Conduent Breach Surges to Over 25M, Could Be Largest in US History
item.description: <p>New state filings suggest the Conduent breach may affect more than 25 million Americans, with Texas alone reporting 15.4 million impacted residents.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-conduent-data-breach-25-million-largest-us-history/">Conduent Breach Surges to Over 25M, Could Be Largest in US History</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Aminu Abdullahi

item.title: APT28 Targeted European Entities Using Webhook-Based Macro Malware
item.description: The Russia-linked state-sponsored threat actor tracked as APT28 has been attributed to a new campaign targeting specific entities in Western and Central Europe. The activity, per S2 Grupo's LAB52 threat intelligence team, was active between September 2025 and January 2026. It has been codenamed Operation MacroMaze. "The campaign relies on basic tooling and the exploitation of legitimate services
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: 600+ FortiGate Devices Hacked by AI-Armed Amateur
item.description: A Russian-speaking hacker used generative AI to compromise the FortiGate firewalls, targeting credentials and backups for possible follow-on ransomware attacks.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Wormable XMRig Campaign Uses BYOVD Exploit and Time-Based Logic Bomb
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new cryptojacking campaign that uses pirated software bundles as lures to deploy a bespoke XMRig miner program on compromised hosts. "Analysis of the recovered dropper, persistence triggers, and mining payload reveals a sophisticated, multi-stage infection prioritizing maximum cryptocurrency mining hashrate, often destabilizing the victim
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Over 200K Australian Driver’s Licences Exposed in youX Cyber Breach
item.description: <p>A youX breach exposed sensitive borrower data in Australia, including over 200,000 driver’s licence numbers, raising fraud and phishing risks.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-youx-data-breach-australia-drivers-licence-exposure/">Over 200K Australian Driver’s Licences Exposed in youX Cyber Breach</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Aminu Abdullahi

item.title: Shai-Hulud-Like Worm Targets Developers via npm and AI Tools
item.description: Supply chain worm mimicking Shai-Hulud malware spread via malicious npm packages, targeting AI tools has been identified by security researchers

item.title: Fraud Investigation Reveals Sophisticated Python Malware
item.description: Sophisticated Python malware uncovered in fraud probe shows obfuscation, disposable infrastructure

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Double-Tap Skimmers, PromptSpy AI, 30Tbps DDoS, Docker Malware & More
item.description: Security news rarely moves in a straight line. This week, it feels more like a series of sharp turns, some happening quietly in the background, others playing out in public view. The details are different, but the pressure points are familiar. Across devices, cloud services, research labs, and even everyday apps, the line between normal behavior and hidden risk keeps getting thinner. Tools
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Russian Cyber Threat Actor Uses GenAI to Compromise Fortinet Firewalls
item.description: A low-skilled Russian-speaking attacker has used GenAI tools to help deploy a successful attack workflow targeting FortiGate instances

item.title: On the Security of Password Managers
item.description: <p><a href="https://arstechnica.com/security/2026/02/password-managers-promise-that-they-cant-see-your-vaults-isnt-always-true/">Good article</a> on password managers that secretly have a backdoor.</p> <blockquote><p>New research shows that these claims aren’t true in all cases, particularly when account recovery is in place or password managers are set to share vaults or organize users into groups. The researchers reverse-engineered or closely analyzed Bitwarden, Dashlane, and LastPass and identified ways that someone with control over the server­&#8212;either administrative or the result of a compromise­&#8212;can, in fact, steal data and, in some cases, entire vaults. The researchers also devised other attacks that can weaken the encryption to the point that ciphertext can be converted to plaintext...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: How Exposed Endpoints Increase Risk Across LLM Infrastructure
item.description: As more organizations run their own Large Language Models (LLMs), they are also deploying more internal services and Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) to support those models. Modern security risks are being introduced less from the models themselves and more from the infrastructure that serves, connects and automates the model. Each new LLM endpoint expands the attack surface, often in
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Leading Semiconductor Supplier Advantest Hit by Ransomware Attack
item.description: Advantest, a Japanese specialist in testing computer chips for major semiconductor manufacturers, has deployed incident response protocols following a cybersecurity incident

item.title: Jackpotting Surge Costs Banks Over $20m, Warns FBI
item.description: A new FBI Flash alert claims $20m was lost to ATM jackpotting attacks in 2025 alone

item.title: Malicious npm Packages Harvest Crypto Keys, CI Secrets, and API Tokens
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed what they say is an active "Shai-Hulud-like" supply chain worm campaign that has leveraged a cluster of at least 19 malicious npm packages to enable credential harvesting and cryptocurrency key theft. The campaign has been codenamed SANDWORM_MODE by supply chain security company Socket. As with prior Shai-Hulud attack waves, the malicious code embedded
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Faking it on the phone: How to tell if a voice call is AI or not
item.description: Can you believe your ears? Increasingly, the answer is no. Here’s what’s at stake for your business, and how to beat the deepfakers.

item.title: University of Mississippi Medical Center Still Offline After Ransomware Attack
item.description: University of Mississippi Medical Center is still scrambling to respond to a ransomware attack last Thursday

item.title: MuddyWater Targets MENA Organizations with GhostFetch, CHAR, and HTTP_VIP
item.description: The Iranian hacking group known as MuddyWater (aka Earth Vetala, Mango Sandstorm, and MUDDYCOAST) has targeted several organizations and individuals mainly located across the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region as part of a new campaign codenamed Operation Olalampo. The activity, first observed on January 26, 2026, has resulted in the deployment of new malware families that share
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: AI-Assisted Threat Actor Compromises 600+ FortiGate Devices in 55 Countries
item.description: A Russian-speaking, financially motivated threat actor has been observed taking advantage of commercial generative artificial intelligence (AI) services to compromise over 600 FortiGate devices located in 55 countries. That's according to new findings from Amazon Threat Intelligence, which said it observed the activity between January 11 and February 18, 2026. "No exploitation of FortiGate
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Anthropic Launches Claude Code Security for AI-Powered Vulnerability Scanning
item.description: Artificial intelligence (AI) company Anthropic has begun to roll out a new security feature for Claude Code that can scan a user's software codebase for vulnerabilities and suggest patches. The capability, called Claude Code Security, is currently available in a limited research preview to Enterprise and Team customers. "It scans codebases for security vulnerabilities and suggests targeted
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CISA Adds Two Actively Exploited Roundcube Flaws to KEV Catalog
item.description:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Friday added two security flaws impacting Roundcube webmail software to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation. The vulnerabilities in question are listed below -
CVE-2025-49113 (CVSS score: 9.9) - A deserialization of untrusted data vulnerability that allows remote code
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: EC-Council Expands AI Certification Portfolio to Strengthen U.S. AI Workforce Readiness and Security
item.description: With $5.5 trillion in global AI risk exposure and 700,000 U.S. workers needing reskilling, four new AI certifications and Certified CISO v4 help close the gap between AI adoption and workforce readiness. EC-Council, creator of the world-renowned Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH) credential and a global leader in applied cybersecurity education, today launched its Enterprise AI Credential Suite,
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: PayPal Flaw Exposed Email Addresses, Social Security Numbers for 6 Months
item.description: <p>PayPal disclosed a software error in its Working Capital platform that exposed sensitive customer data, including Social Security numbers, for months in 2025.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-paypal-working-capital-data-exposure-2025/">PayPal Flaw Exposed Email Addresses, Social Security Numbers for 6 Months</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Ken Underhill

item.title: Friday Squid Blogging: Squid Cartoon
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Attackers Use New Tool to Scan for React2Shell Exposure
item.description: Researchers say threat actors wielded the sophisticated — and unfortunately named — toolkit to target high-value networks for React2Shell exploitation.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson

item.title: ‘Starkiller’ Phishing Service Proxies Real Login Pages, MFA
item.description: Most phishing websites are little more than static copies of login pages for popular online destinations, and they are often quickly taken down by anti-abuse activists and security firms. But a stealthy new phishing-as-a-service offering lets customers sidestep both of these pitfalls: It uses cleverly disguised links to load the target brand's real website, and then acts as a relay between the target and the legitimate site -- forwarding the victim's username, password and multi-factor authentication (MFA) code to the legitimate site and returning its responses.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: 'God-Like' Attack Machines: AI Agents Ignore Security Policies
item.description: Microsoft Copilot recently summarized and leaked user emails; but any AI agent will go above and beyond to complete assigned tasks, even breaking through their carefully designed guardrails.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos

item.title: Google Blocked 1.75M Harmful Apps From Play Store in 2025
item.description: <p>Google used AI-driven review systems to block 1.75 million policy-violating apps and ban 80,000 developer accounts in 2025, expanding Play Store and Android security enforcement.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-google-ai-blocked-1-75-million-apps-2025/">Google Blocked 1.75M Harmful Apps From Play Store in 2025</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Lessons From AI Hacking: Every Model, Every Layer Is Risky
item.description: After two years of finding flaws in AI infrastructure, two Wiz researchers advise security pros to worry less about prompt injection and more about vulnerabilities.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos

item.title: Microsoft: Critical Security Issue Found in Windows Notepad
item.description: <p>Microsoft patches CVE-2026-20841, a high-severity Windows Notepad flaw that could allow code execution via malicious Markdown files.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/critical-windows-notepad-flaw-february-2026/">Microsoft: Critical Security Issue Found in Windows Notepad</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: BeyondTrust Flaw Used for Web Shells, Backdoors, and Data Exfiltration
item.description: Threat actors have been observed exploiting a recently disclosed critical security flaw impacting BeyondTrust Remote Support (RS) and Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products to conduct a wide range of malicious actions, including deploying VShell and&nbsp; The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-1731 (CVSS score: 9.9), allows attackers to execute operating system commands in the context of the
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Cline CLI 2.3.0 Supply Chain Attack Installed OpenClaw on Developer Systems
item.description: In yet another software supply chain attack, the open-source, artificial intelligence (AI)-powered coding assistant Cline CLI was updated to stealthily install OpenClaw, a self-hosted autonomous AI agent that has become exceedingly popular in the past few months. "On February 17, 2026, at 3:26 AM PT, an unauthorized party used a compromised npm publish token to publish an update to Cline CLI
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Latin America's Cyber Maturity Lags Threat Landscape
item.description: The slower pace of upgrades has the unintended impact of creating a haven for attackers, especially for initial access brokers and ransomware gangs.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Dramatic Escalation in Frequency and Power of DDoS Attacks
item.description: DDoS attack frequency has risen to ‘alarming levels,’ warns Radware report

item.title: Ring Cancels Its Partnership with Flock
item.description: <p>It&#8217;s a demonstration of how toxic the surveillance-tech company Flock has become when Amazon&#8217;s Ring <a href="https://www.theverge.com/news/878447/ring-flock-partnership-canceled">cancels</a> the partnership between the two companies.</p> <p>As Hamilton Nolan advises, <a href="https://www.hamiltonnolan.com/p/remove-your-ring-camera-with-a-claw">remove</a> your Ring doorbell.</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: ClickFix Campaign Abuses Compromised Sites to Deploy MIMICRAT Malware
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new ClickFix campaign that abuses compromised legitimate sites to deliver a previously undocumented remote access trojan (RAT) called MIMICRAT (aka AstarionRAT). "The campaign demonstrates a high level of operational sophistication: compromised sites spanning multiple industries and geographies serve as delivery infrastructure, a multi-stage
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Android Malware Hijacks Google Gemini to Stay Hidden
item.description: A new Android malware implant using Google Gemini to perform persistence tasks was discovered on VirusTotal and analyzed by ESET

item.title: Identity Cyber Scores: The New Metric Shaping Cyber Insurance in 2026
item.description: With one in three cyber-attacks now involving compromised employee accounts, insurers and regulators are placing far greater emphasis on identity posture when assessing cyber risk.&nbsp; For many organizations, however, these assessments remain largely opaque. Elements such as password hygiene, privileged access management, and the extent of multi-factor authentication (MFA) coverage are
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Ukrainian National Sentenced to 5 Years in North Korea IT Worker Fraud Case
item.description: A 29-year-old Ukrainian national has been sentenced to five years in prison in the U.S. for his role in facilitating North Korea's fraudulent information technology (IT) worker scheme. In November 2025, Oleksandr "Alexander" Didenko pleaded guilty to wire fraud conspiracy and aggravated identity theft for stealing the identities of U.S. citizens and selling them to IT workers to help them land
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: FBI Reports 1,900 ATM Jackpotting Incidents Since 2020, $20M Lost in 2025
item.description: The U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has warned of an increase in ATM jackpotting incidents across the country, leading to losses of more than $20 million in 2025. The agency said 1,900 ATM jackpotting incidents have been reported since 2020, out of which 700 took place last year. In December 2025, the U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) said about $40.73 million has been collectively
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Former Google Engineers Indicted Over Trade Secret Transfers to Iran
item.description: Two former Google engineers and one of their husbands have been indicted in the U.S. for allegedly committing trade secret theft from the search giant and other tech firms and transferring the information to unauthorized locations, including Iran. Samaneh Ghandali, 41, and her husband Mohammadjavad Khosravi (aka Mohammad Khosravi), 40, along with her sister Soroor Ghandali, 32, have been accused
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Essential Eight in Australia: Lift Maturity Without More Tools
item.description: <p>Australia’s Essential Eight demands measurable progress. Learn how CIOs can improve security maturity without expanding tools or increasing costs.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/tr-apac-essential-eight-australia-maturity-without-more-tools/">Essential Eight in Australia: Lift Maturity Without More Tools</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: David Curry

item.title: Emerging Chiplet Designs Spark Fresh Cybersecurity Challenges
item.description: As scaled-down circuits with limited functions redefine computing for AI systems and autonomous vehicles, their flexibility demands new approaches to safeguard critical infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Agam Shah

item.title: Supply Chain Attack Secretly Installs OpenClaw for Cline Users
item.description: The malicious version of Cline's npm package — 2.3.0 — was downloaded more than 4,000 times before it was removed.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: Best-in-Class 'Starkiller' Phishing Kit Bypasses MFA
item.description: A user-friendly PhaaS tool beats standard methods for detecting phishing attacks by live-proxying legitimate login sites.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson

item.title: Abu Dhabi Finance Week Exposed VIP Passport Details
item.description: Unprotected cloud data sends the wrong signal at a time when the emirate's trying to attract investors and establish itself as a global financial center.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan

item.title: AI Agents Are Quietly Redefining Enterprise Security Risk
item.description: <p>AI agents now operate across enterprise systems, creating new risk via prompt injection, plugins, and persistent memory. Here’s how to adapt security.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-ai-agents-enterprise-security-zero-trust-moltbook-risk/">AI Agents Are Quietly Redefining Enterprise Security Risk</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Tim Freestone

item.title: PromptSpy Android Malware Abuses Gemini AI to Automate Recent-Apps Persistence
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered what they say is the first Android malware that abuses Gemini, Google's generative artificial intelligence (AI) chatbot, as part of its execution flow and achieves persistence. The malware has been codenamed PromptSpy by ESET. The malware is equipped to capture lockscreen data, block uninstallation efforts, gather device information, take screenshots,
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: INTERPOL Operation Red Card 2.0 Arrests 651 in African Cybercrime Crackdown
item.description: An international cybercrime operation against online scams has led to 651 arrests and recovered more than $4.3 million as part of an effort led by law enforcement agencies from 16 African countries. The initiative, codenamed Operation Red Card 2.0, took place between December 8, 2025 and January 30, 2026, according to INTERPOL. It targeted infrastructure and actors behind high-yield investment
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft Patches CVE-2026-26119 Privilege Escalation in Windows Admin Center
item.description: Microsoft has disclosed a now-patched security flaw in Windows Admin Center that could allow an attacker to escalate their privileges. Windows Admin Center is a locally deployed, browser-based management tool set that lets users manage their Windows Clients, Servers, and Clusters without the need for connecting to the cloud. The high-severity vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-26119, carries a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Remcos RAT Expands Real-Time Surveillance Capabilities
item.description: New Remcos RAT variant enhances real-time surveillance and evasion techniques to compromise Windows

item.title: Figure Data Breach Exposes Nearly 1 Million Customers Online
item.description: <p>Fintech lender Figure suffered a social-engineering breach that led to a data dump online. Have I Been Pwned found 967,200 exposed email records.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-figure-data-breach-967200-email-records/">Figure Data Breach Exposes Nearly 1 Million Customers Online</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Liz Ticong

item.title: Coffee with the Council Podcast: PCI SSC Publishes First-Ever Annual Report
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: Industrial-Scale Fake Coretax Apps Drive $2m Fraud in Indonesia
item.description: Fraud campaign exploiting Indonesia’s Coretax resulted in $1.5m to $2m in losses via malicious apps

item.title: Connected &amp; Compromised: When IoT Devices Turn Into Threats
item.description: Reused passwords, a lack of network segmentation, and poor sanitization processes make the Internet of Things' attack surfaces more dangerous.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: OpenSSL RCE, Foxit 0-Days, Copilot Leak, AI Password Flaws & 20+ Stories
item.description: The cyber threat space doesn’t pause, and this week makes that clear. New risks, new tactics, and new security gaps are showing up across platforms, tools, and industries — often all at the same time. Some developments are headline-level. Others sit in the background but carry long-term impact. Together, they shape how defenders need to think about exposure, response, and preparedness right now
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Industrial Control System Vulnerabilities Hit Record Highs
item.description: Forescout paper reveals ICS advisories hit a record 508 in 2025

item.title: Malicious AI
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Starkiller: New ‘Commercial-Grade’ Phishing Kit Bypasses MFA
item.description: A new cybercriminal toolkit uses proxies to mimic popular online services and represents a “significant escalation in phishing infrastructure,” warn researchers at Abnormal

item.title: From Exposure to Exploitation: How AI Collapses Your Response Window
item.description: We’ve all seen this before: a developer deploys a new cloud workload and grants overly broad permissions just to keep the sprint moving. An engineer generates a "temporary" API key for testing and forgets to revoke it. In the past, these were minor operational risks, debts you’d eventually pay down during a slower cycle. In 2026, “Eventually” is Now But today, within minutes, AI-powered
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Flaws in Popular Software Development App Extensions Allow Data Exfiltration
item.description: Four serious new vulnerabilities affect Microsoft Visual Studio Code, Cursor and Windsurf extensions, three of which remain unpatched

item.title: PromptSpy ushers in the era of Android threats using GenAI
item.description: ESET researchers discover PromptSpy, the first known Android malware to abuse generative AI in its execution flow

item.title: Fake IPTV Apps Spread Massiv Android Malware Targeting Mobile Banking Users
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new Android trojan called Massiv that's designed to facilitate device takeover (DTO) attacks for financial theft. The malware, according to ThreatFabric, masquerades as seemingly harmless IPTV apps to deceive victims, indicating that the activity is primarily singling out users looking for the online TV applications. "This new threat, while
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Researchers Reveal Six New OpenClaw Vulnerabilities
item.description: Endor Labs has published details of six new vulnerabilities in popular AI assistant OpenClaw

item.title: CRESCENTHARVEST Campaign Targets Iran Protest Supporters With RAT Malware
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new campaign dubbed CRESCENTHARVEST, likely targeting supporters of Iran's ongoing protests to conduct information theft and long-term espionage. The Acronis Threat Research Unit (TRU) said it observed the activity after January 9, with the attacks designed to deliver a malicious payload that serves as a remote access trojan (RAT) and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Is Poshmark safe? How to buy and sell without getting scammed
item.description: Like any other marketplace, the social commerce platform has its share of red flags. It pays to know what to look for so you can shop or sell without headaches.

item.title: More Than 40% of South Africans Were Scammed in 2025
item.description: Survey underscores the reality that scammers follow &quot;scalable opportunities and low friction,&quot; rather than rich targets that tend to be better protected.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson
